The FDA is worried about the risk of patients accidentally overdosing on ibuprofen. You may think that taking more ibuprofen than recommended means that you just take extra tablets (or capsules), and you'd be right. However, some medications for ibuprofen are sold in blister packaging with 80mg tablets in a pack that's divided into two. This makes it easy, the FDA believes, to double the dose accidentally, overdosing on the medication.

In a safety communication, the FDA noted that more than 12,000 people visited the ER for non-fatal ibuprofen overdoses between 2004 and 2013. Most of these overdose incidents involved children younger than 5 years of age who might have accidentally ingested ibuprofen. So what do the manufacturers of ibuprofen medication plan to do?

As per the FDA's request, manufacturers of ibuprofen medication have committed to reduce the strength of their 200mg tablets to 120mg, except for generic versions. The move is intended to prevent "unintentional ingestion of higher quantities of ibuprofen."

If you're taking ibuprofen, it's important to be aware of the risks. The good news is that you don't need to rush to the doctor over this: the FDA still gives ibuprofen its lowest risk level despite the overdoses.

The results are the same and cornstarch also works better than flour to thicken a sauce. I also suggest that you make your roux in a microwavable measuring cup. This is important. When your roux is dark enough, add a quarter cup of vegetable broth (or water if you have no broth), stirring vigorously with a fork. Then, pour your roux mixture into a sauce pan and add 2 tablespoons of vegan soy butter (such as Earth Balance), 2 tablespoons of Nutritional yeast (sometimes called Parmesan Flakes to make it thicker), 1 teaspoon of Dijon Mustard, 1/4 teaspoon of Garlic powder (or finely minced garlic), 1/4 teaspoon of salt, and 1/4 teaspoon of black pepper. To simmer your sauce, bring it to boiling temperature for just a few seconds, then turn down the heat and let it simmer away until it thickens (with continual stirring). model_input: I mean the first president of the United States.
prediction:
The one that wrote the letter. The one that got shot. The one that slept with his mistress.
And as a poet who thinks all the time about words and their sounds it seems a little odd that I've never gotten around to reading any of his poetry. Maybe it's because I've been busy trying to make sense of my own country's politics, and the way I'm feeling about them.
But I was reading The New Yorker and came across one of his poems. I hadn't known that he had written, before and after he became president, all about getting on with politics in a republic. And, of course, as you might expect, it sounds even more contemporary than it is.
The poem is 17 lines. Here are the first 12:
The eye of the voter is not easy / to displease and to please / But the wise man takes pains / to know at what cost the viceroyalty / of republics may be vindicated / by the sacrifice of the rights of the many / not the whole of the few.
And it goes on from there. What I like is the way it sets one thought about democracy and politics against another (the eye of the voter being a politician or politician's desire) and in the process, exposes a truth that's easy to miss, that a democracy must find a way to balance the interests of the individual, the interests of power (the viceroyalty is how Hamilton made power for himself), and the interests of the community (the rights of the many, though it might seem a more obvious virtue). It's so easy for this to go off course, and all the more reason to remember (as these eight lines will help you do) where it is we have agreed to place our trust.
It is something of a national embarrassment that our president seems incapable of this sort of thinking, or perhaps even acknowledging the possibility of more than one perspective on an issue. But maybe that just means it's something we can all help with.

With my research, we were able to identify and characterize the mechanism behind the change in boiling points with temperature.
For starters at sea level, mercury boils at -38°C. That's pretty cold. However, the higher in elevation you get, the lower the atmospheric pressure. As I mentioned in my previous post, the gas above our sea level atmosphere holds us up. This air (called a vapor) exerts a pressure on the earth below. For example, on top of mount Everest the pressure is one-third of sea level pressure. So if the pressure is lower, that means the air isn't holding us up as much. As the air pressure decreases, the boiling point of liquids decrease as well. The change in temperature is the same for all fluids. If a beaker of water with a known amount of water can be observed to boil at 100 degrees Celsius at sea level, it can be observed to boil around 90 degrees Celsius somewhere like Denver (near the top of the Rocky Mountains), or around 68 degrees Celsius at the summit of Mt. Everest. This holds up for most liquids on Earth.
The relationship between temperature and pressure was not an easy one to identify at first. Early observations were plagued by the fact that the gas that was assumed to exert the force on a liquid would push down on the liquid from above. As it turns out, the reason for this mistake was that they were observing the wrong effect. In order to study pressure and temperature, one must first use a tool with which to observe the two. In the case of temperature, it's easy: we have thermometers for that. But how does one observe pressure?
